snippet: Julia Bluhm, an eighth grader from Maine, petitioned Seventeen magazine to feature unaltered photos, to give girls more reasonable body images.
abstract: Jim Dwyer About New York column on Maine eighth grader Julia Bluhm, who has personally delivered a 46,000-signature petition to Seventeen magazine, asking it to feature unaltered photos of 'real girls,' showing normal body types and skin problems; Bluhm is leading a national fight through her blog Spark against the destructive misrepresentation of beauty in media. Photos (M)
lead_paragraph: In Julia Bluhm's ballet class, girls arrived and often declared that they were having a fat day. Or that their skin was pimply or blemished. Or that they looked disgusting. When she hears complaints in her middle school, where she is in the eighth grade, Julia said, she has one answer: ''Are you crazy?'' Then, she said, she came up with another answer, thumbing through one of her favorite magazines, Seventeen.

headline.main: A Real Girl, 14, Takes a Stand Against the Flawless Faces in Magazines
